titleStmt.title: The confession and execution of the five prisoners that suffered at Tyburn, on Friday the 4th of June, 1680. Viz. Thomas Newell, John Biggs, [bracket] both guilty of burglary, and also of breaking prison lately out of Newgate. John Eakins, one of the same crew for burglary. George D. a marshals man, for murdering a child. And Richard Spykeman, for burglary. : With an account of their behaviour after condemnation, and at the place of execution.

titleStmt.title: The confession and execution of the five prisoners that suffered at Tyburn, on Friday the 4th of June, 1680. Viz. Thomas Newell, John Biggs, [bracket] both guilty of burglary, and also of breaking prison lately out of Newgate. John Eakins, one of the same crew for burglary. George D. a marshals man, for murdering a child. And Richard Spykeman, for burglary. : With an account of their behaviour after condemnation, and at the place of execution.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: THE CONFESSION and EXECUTION OF THE Five PRISONERS That Suffered at TYBÆ²RN, On Friday the 4th of June, 1680.

list.head: VIZ.
list.item:
Thomas Newell,
John Biggs,
Both guilty of Burglary, and alÅ¿o of breaking PriÅ¿on lately out of Newgate.
John Eakins, One of the Å¿ame Crew for Burglary.
George D. A MarÅ¿hals man, for Murdering a Child.

div.head: With an Account of their Behaviour after Condemnation, and at the place of Execution.
div.p: THe SeÅ¿Å¿ions for London and MiddleÅ¿ex began May the 26th, and continued to the 28th, where were in all Condemned fourteen perÅ¿ons, four Women and ten Men; all which women were by a Jury of Matrons found Å¿everally to be quick with Child, and Å¿o Reprieved till they were Delivered; and of the men five alÅ¿o, who had not Å¿o notoriouÅ¿ly offended, as to be totally excluded from Mercy, were put by and exempted from the Severity of JuÅ¿tice.

John Newel and John Biggs had formerly been notoriouÅ¿ly Guilty of divers Burglaries, and particularly of breaking out of the Goal of Newgate, and being on new Facts ImpriÅ¿oned at St. Albans, they were thence removed; and had not the confidence to plead otherwiÅ¿e than Guilty, as well knowing there were Å¿o many Indictments againÅ¿t them, as would certainly do their buÅ¿ineÅ¿s.
John Eakins was one of the Å¿ame Crew, an old Malefactor, who Å¿o oft had received Mercy, that now he could expect or hope for it no more.

Richard Spykeman was alÅ¿o Condemned for Burglary, having run through the whole courÅ¿e or Å¿tage of Villany. He began firÅ¿t with Dear-Å¿tealing, and as the leaÅ¿t Rogueries tranÅ¿acted with Impunity, prompt on to the greateÅ¿t, and Å¿ingle, Å¿mall, vicious Attempts grow up in time to be perfect Habits; Å¿o he after various over-paÅ¿t Crimes, having been a Water-pad, &c. became Å¿o far hardned, as not to Å¿tick at any nefarious Acts whatÅ¿oever; and therefore as an
Incorrigible Offender, was now thought fit to be mow'd down by the Scythe of JuÅ¿tice.

George D. was an Officer belonging to the MarÅ¿hals-Court: his crime, for killing the Child of a poor Man; (whom he ArreÅ¿ted) becauÅ¿e it cryed out to Å¿ee its Father miÅ¿-uÅ¿ed. At the time of his Condemnation, he Å¿eemed very remorÅ¿eful for his Offence, but afterwards appeared (as Å¿ome Å¿uppoÅ¿ed) more expectant and Å¿ollicitous for a Temporal, than any other Pardon.

p.hi: The Å¿ubÅ¿tance of the Å¿everal Crimes as were found at the SeÅ¿Å¿ions were as follows.

div.p: A remarkable Tryal was about the Murder of a ConÅ¿table at the Armitage-Å¿tairs, for which a poor Waterman Å¿tood Indicted; there were abundance of WitneÅ¿Å¿es examined, and the Tryal was very tedious. But the Å¿um of the matter was to this effect: Some Scotchmen, half a dozen or more in all, belonging to a Ship that lay in the River, having been on Å¿hore, and 'tis probable taking plentiful Cups, as Sailors uÅ¿e, about nine of the Clock at night were returning to their VeÅ¿Å¿el; and in order to get to their own Boat, Å¿ome of them Å¿tept through a Boat of the PriÅ¿oners, in which there was a Boy, whom a Scotch boy of this company either trod upon or affronted, which made him Å¿trike him; and the Scotchmen as faÅ¿t fell on the EngliÅ¿h-boy, who ran and called his MaÅ¿ter the PriÅ¿oner, and Å¿o the Fray encreaÅ¿ed: to quell which, the now PriÅ¿oner called the ConÅ¿table living juÅ¿t by, and who was his intimate Friend; for at his houÅ¿e he uÅ¿ed commonly to leave Å¿everal Tackling belonging to his Boat, and other offices of KindneÅ¿s frequently paÅ¿s'd between them. But Å¿o it hapned in the Scuffle, it being pretty dark, the ConÅ¿table's Brains were beat out, Å¿uppoÅ¿ed to be done with one of their Poies, or Hooks, which they uÅ¿e with their Boats. The Scotchmen Å¿hifted for themÅ¿elves and got away, and a perÅ¿on that was there alledged, that the now PriÅ¿oner Å¿truck the fatal Blow; but beÅ¿ides that there was no former Malice, Å¿o 'twas a moÅ¿t unlikely thing, that he Å¿hould go to hurt one that was his Friend, and came thither at his requeÅ¿t to aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t him. So that upon the whole matter, it was believed Å¿uch witneÅ¿s might poÅ¿Å¿ibly be miÅ¿taken, in Å¿o great an Hurry and ConfuÅ¿ion; Å¿o that the Waterman, who had the repute of an honeÅ¿t, civil, quiet man amongÅ¿t his Neighbours, was Acquitted.

A PerÅ¿on was Convicted for a Robbery in MiddleÅ¿ex, committed in a Victualling-houÅ¿e that Å¿tood alone, remote from Neighbours, whither the PriÅ¿oner, for Å¿ome time before the Exploit was committed, uÅ¿ed for Å¿ome days frequently to reÅ¿ort, and Å¿eem'd a very civil GueÅ¿t: but having laid the DeÅ¿ign, he and two or three more of his Companions came one Evening, about 9 or 10 of the Clock, before the Doors were Å¿hut, there being no body there but the Woman of the houÅ¿e and her Maid; where preÅ¿ently Å¿wearing in a furious manner, they begun to demand her Keys, and this Fellow held the Woman below, whilÅ¿t the reÅ¿t went up Å¿tairs and ranÅ¿ackt her Trunks, &c. taking away in Money and Goods to the value of near Twenty Pounds; and then binding the Woman and her Servant, went away with the Booty. The Woman, whilÅ¿t the reÅ¿t were making havock above, Å¿eeing her Å¿elf like to be quite undone, wept bitterly, and Å¿aid to the now PriÅ¿oner who held her below, Alas, Sir, I did not imagine that you would have dealt thus by me! To which all the AnÅ¿wer the hard-hearted Villain returned, was with a Å¿cornful Smile, No indeed Landlady, I believe you did not. He had then a Perriwig on, and other Cloaths, but the Woman knew him by
his Voice; and the Maid Å¿wore directy that he was the man: And Å¿o he was found Guilty.

An old fellow, one of thoÅ¿e that broke out of the Goal, and upon their retaking at St. Albons being brought up, were publickly expoÅ¿ed with Collars about their Necks, to the view of the people without Newgate, having now Å¿everal Indictments againÅ¿t him; when he was required to plead to the firÅ¿t, Å¿aid, He was Guilty of that and whatÅ¿oever elÅ¿e Å¿hould be brought againÅ¿t him; and being thereupon asked, Why he would plead Å¿o unadviÅ¿edly, and whether he had a minde to caÅ¿t away his Life, anÅ¿wered, That he were as good caÅ¿t it away himÅ¿elf, for he was Å¿ure he Å¿hould be Hang'd. And indeed he had no reaÅ¿on to promiÅ¿e himÅ¿elf a better DeÅ¿tiny, for he had been a notorious HouÅ¿ebreaker, and the occaÅ¿ion of many other mens ruine, by his bad Example, and pernicious CounÅ¿el and Enticement.

A kind of DiÅ¿tracted Woman was Arraigned for Å¿tealing a great Å¿um of Money; but Å¿he Å¿eemed to take no notice of, nor underÅ¿tand any thing that was Å¿aid againÅ¿t her; and the Officers of the Jail affirmed, that ever Å¿ince her Commitment, Å¿he appeared to them as a perÅ¿on Lunatick, or not compos mentis; and therefore in reÅ¿pect of her condition Å¿he was Å¿et aÅ¿ide.

A young man was found guilty of a Felony and Burghlary in London, breaking into an HouÅ¿e that he was well acquainted at in the night, and Å¿tealing thence a Gold Watch and other things, to the value of one hundred pounds and upwards.

A Bailey belonging to the MarÅ¿hals-Court, going to ArreÅ¿t a poor man for a Debt of Å¿even Å¿hillings, and according to the uÅ¿ual Cruelty and barbarouÅ¿neÅ¿s of thoÅ¿e Å¿avage Cattle, beating and dragging him along; a Child of the mans, Å¿eeing her Father Å¿o uÅ¿ed, cryed out: whereupon this bruitiÅ¿h fellow turn'd about and Å¿truck the poor Child a blow on the head with a great Cudgel, Å¿o furiouÅ¿ly, that a Gentleman that Å¿aw it, teÅ¿tified it was enough to have knockt down the Å¿touteÅ¿t man. However, the Child was for the preÅ¿ent recovered to life, and by the help of a Surgeon, the Wound in Å¿ome time Å¿eemed to be healed, but Å¿till Å¿he complained of her Head, and Å¿eemed to languiÅ¿h ever after, and not long after dyed; Å¿o that it was concluded he was the occaÅ¿ion of her death, and accordingly the Jury found him guilty.

An Ale-houÅ¿e-keeper was likewiÅ¿e Indicted for killing a poor weak man, whom 'twas Å¿aid he kickt; but the proof not being poÅ¿itive, and the party deceaÅ¿ed having long been known to be very infirm, he was acquitted.

Two Shop-lifts were Convicted of Felony for Å¿tealing of three pieces of Damask Silk out of a Å¿hop in London, where they came pretending to buy Diaper, and whilÅ¿t the man went to reach it, they got the Å¿ilk; but he Å¿oon miÅ¿Å¿ed it, and purÅ¿uing them, they according to the uÅ¿ual tricks of Practitioners in that MyÅ¿tery were Å¿een to drop it.

A Woman that came to be a Servant in a Gentlemans houÅ¿e, before Å¿he had been there five days, took an opportunity to Rob them of a conÅ¿iderable parcel of Plate and Å¿ome Money, and carried it down into the Countrey by a Carrier; being diÅ¿covered, was now Indicted together with the Å¿aid Carrier, and Å¿he was found Guilty: but the Carrier being a very honeÅ¿t man, and nothing Criminal proved againÅ¿t him, was deÅ¿ervedly Acquitted.

Two perÅ¿ons were charg'd with High-TreaÅ¿on for Coyning, and Å¿ome Å¿uÅ¿picious CircumÅ¿tances were made out; but if they deÅ¿ign'd any Å¿uch thing, they were but Bunglers at the Trade; and there being no punctual Proof, they were found Not Guilty.

Let theÅ¿e poor wretches Woe be our warning, and their Execution every Readers Admonition. ConÅ¿ider I pray! with what terrour did theÅ¿e miÅ¿erable Criminals Å¿tand at the Old-Bailey-Bar; their hands even trembling whilÅ¿t lift up for Tryal, and their very lips quaking, whilÅ¿t againÅ¿t the Dictates of their ConÅ¿ciences they pleaded Not Guilty. Their Countenance Condemning them before the Judge, and their Fears, (puÅ¿ht on by ConÅ¿ciouÅ¿neÅ¿s of their guilt) Executing them both before, and more Å¿everely than the Hangman. Yet this Judge is but a man, that muÅ¿t quickly dye himÅ¿elf; that Sentence of Death which he can pronounce, is already paÅ¿Å¿ed by Nature upon the moÅ¿t innocent. That act of death which the Law inflicteth on theÅ¿e men, is but momentary, and who does not know whether himÅ¿elf Å¿hall not dye more painful than any of theÅ¿e?

With what horrour, O God! Å¿hall each guilty Soul Å¿tand before his dreadful Tribunal, in the day of the great AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿es of the world, that has not an intereÅ¿t (on GoÅ¿pel-terms) in thy ChriÅ¿t and our JeÅ¿us? whilÅ¿t there is the unapproachable preÅ¿ence of an infinite MajeÅ¿ty to daunt him, a fierce and clamarous ConÅ¿cience to give Evidence againÅ¿t him, Legions of terrible Devils waiting upon him, a gulf of unquenchable fire ready to receive him; whilÅ¿t the glory of the Judge is no leÅ¿s confounding, than the cruelty of the Tormenters, where the Sentance is unavoidable, and the Execution everlaÅ¿ting. Why then, (to every Reader be it Å¿poken) do not theÅ¿e Terrors of thee our God, make us wiÅ¿e to hold a private SeÅ¿Å¿ions upon our own Souls and Actions? that being acquitted by our own Hearts, we may not be Condemned by thee, and being judged by our Å¿elves, we may not be Condemned, though by, yet at leaÅ¿t not with, the world:

As for Walter Gilman who was found guilty on two Indictments by the MiddleÅ¿ex Jury, and about whom one of the London Jury was Confin'd, for not finding him guilty of Å¿tealing a Watch, he was Reprieved.
The Five before-mentioned were carried in two Carts, Three in the firÅ¿t, and Two in the laÅ¿t, of whom the MarÅ¿hals man Å¿eemed to be very penitent.
